content: If you're online, use Send Later from the File menu on the composition window, or Ctrl+Shift+Enter. This will place the message in the Outbox. When you wish to send the message(s) in Outbox, select Send Unsent Messages from the File menu on the main window, or the Outbox context menu. No need to switch between online and offline.
creator: sfhowes

Many thanks David. Manually changing the server and authentication method allowed me to send emails but not save them locally. Neither could I receive emails.

As a result I tried method 2, removed the account from Thunderbird and then reinstated it. This resolved the matter as Thunderbird automatically chose the correct settings and as a result my outlook account is now fully functional on Thunderbird.

Many thanks for your help.

Paul Keegan.

content: Did you visit that URL? Your email provider is asking that you set authentication for Thunderbird to prove you are a customer of their services. It might be that you have no password or security setting in your SMTP server setup.

creator: wsmwk

content:
From September you'll need to use OAuth2 authentication to use HotMail. As part of the change MicroSoft have been making more frequent password requests of people who still use the old system; I first noticed it around the same time you did but wrote it off as "one of those things" and didn't investigate it deeply.

If you deleted and reinstalled your account the new version should be using OAuth2 by default. What you haven't said is what version of Thunderbird you are using as old ones can't do it — I was using 45 until a few weeks ago when I had to change for this reason. Under Account Settings > Server Settings make sure "Authentication method" says "OAuth2".
creator: thepillenwerfer

content: Just a suggestion, not a solution: - set the 'save as' as desired - exit and restart thunderbird - is the changed setting still in effect? - if not, that indicate that something" i preventing thunderbird from saving the setting at termination. That might be an antivirus program or other software that monitors computer activity.
